question: Does decreased nitric oxide bioavailability cause the development of cerebral vasospasm after subarachnoid hemorrhage? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: Decreased bioavailability of nitric oxide has been associated with the development of cerebral vasospasm.
content.source_2: Despite continuous nitrite administration after subarachnoid hemorrhage, vasospasm rates were unchanged; on day 7 the reduction in right middle cerebral artery area averaged 42% in nitrite-treated monkeys versus 47% with saline (P=0.41), and several nitrite-treated animals developed significant vasospasm.
content.source_3: Across a 7-day observation period, only 1 of 8 control monkeys exhibited significant vasospasm, and vessel caliber remained stable in the others despite documented reductions in nitric oxide bioavailability.
